title: Imprinto: Enhancing Infrared Inkjet Watermarking for Human and Machine Perception
author: Martin Feick (DFKI & Saarland University), Alexandru Luchianov (MIT CSAIL), Xuxin Tang (Virginia Tech & MIT CSAIL), Roderick Wei Xiao Huang (MIT CSAIL), Alexa Siu (Adobe Research), Raul Garcia-Martin (Universidad Carlos III de Madrid & MIT CSAIL), Chang Xiao (Adobe Research), Mustafa Doga Dogan (Adobe Research), ...
background: The paper presents a new method for embedding invisible digital watermarks in printed documents that are only detectable with infrared cameras, merging physical documents with augmented reality experiences.
contribution: Imprinto introduces an infrared inkjet watermarking technique to solve the problem of embedding hidden digital information in documents, achieving high data capacity while remaining invisible to the human eye.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing watermarking methods often compromise the visual aesthetics of printed documents or require complex fabrication techniques.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages off-the-shelf infrared inks and conventional inkjet printing to create seamless invisible watermarks without impacting document design.

key_innovation: The ability to utilize the entire document surface, including text and images, for embedding IR content while maintaining invisibility and high information capacity.
real_world_impact: This technique facilitates new applications in fields such as education, security, and art by allowing for interactive, augmented experiences without cluttering document design. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The experiments conducted focused on specific background colors and lighting conditions, which may limit generalizability.

new_terms.infrared inkjet watermarking: **Infrared inkjet watermarking** refers to a technique of embedding digital content into printed materials using inks that absorb infrared light, making the markings invisible to the naked eye but detectable with infrared sensors.
new_terms.psychophysical experiment: **Psychophysical experiment** is a method used to evaluate human perception and detection thresholds regarding sensory stimuli, aiding in understanding visibility limits.

open_sourcing: The machine learning pipeline used for binarizing captured infrared watermarks will be made open-source.
